name: Pineapple Bromeliad
description: Acanthostachys strobilacea, commonly known as Pineapple Bromeliad or Pineapple Plant, is an epiphytic bromeliad native to tropical regions of South America, particularly Brazil, Paraguay, and Argentina. It belongs to the Bromeliaceae family and features a rosette of stiff, spiny, gray-green leaves (20-40 cm long) arranged in a pineapple-like form. Many bromeliads form central water-holding rosettes (tanks) that create mini ecosystems. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers. The plant displays an upright, rosette-forming growth habit and typically reaches 20-40 cm in height. In its native habitat, it grows as an epiphyte on tree trunks and branches in tropical forests. In terrariums or indoor settings, this plant adds natural beauty with its distinctive pineapple-like form. It's popular among bromeliad enthusiasts for its unique appearance.
careTips: Requires high humidity (60-80%) - ideal for terrariums
Bright indirect light is essential - avoid direct sun
Keep central rosette (tank) filled with water - this is how it absorbs moisture
Well-draining epiphytic mix recommended - orchid bark, sphagnum moss
Native to tropical South America - prefers warm, humid conditions (18-24Â°C)
Epiphytic nature - can be mounted on wood or grown in pots
Can be grown in terrariums, paludariums, or aereriums
Watch for scale insects and mealybugs
After flowering, plant produces offsets (pups) that can be separated
